bibl.title: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, April 4, 1952

div1.p: Rath has accepted the invitation of Rojas and Cabrera to visit in order to advise them on preservation of their Finca San Jose. He believes that the recent Cuban revolution makes it unlikely that the government would be hospitable to initiating legislation to form a Cuban National Trust.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, April 4, 1952

Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
The enclosed copy of my air mail letter to Senora Rojas
is, I believe, self-explanatory. You have paved the way so nicely
and I am delighted, of course, to follow through in this manner.

Like you, I am disturbed by the probable result of the
recent revolution in Cuba. At first I thought that it might make
a trip hardly worthwhile, for I do not see how the National Trust
idea could take root under the present administration. It is in-
conceivable to me that the new government will allow the passage
of enabling legislation. But I then decided to defer to your
thought that now, more than ever, they are anxious for advice. If
perchance you wish to reconsider - for the essence of the National
Trust idea is legislative authorization - do let me know. In the
meantime, I shall begin my preparatory studies, in the hope that
direct conference over a two-day period may evolve some answer.

I shall let you know immediately if I hear directly from
Senora Rojas.
